source.dee88ab3:
import bq_helper
from bq_helper import BigQueryHelper

genomes = bq_helper.BigQueryHelper(active_project="bigquery-public-data", dataset_name="genomics_cannabis")
bq_assistant = BigQueryHelper("bigquery-public-data", "genomics_cannabis")
source.db4796a1:
query = """SELECT reference_name, reference_bases, alternate_bases, variant_id, TYPE, start, m.end
        FROM `bigquery-public-data.genomics_cannabis.MNPR01_201703` m, m.call
        WHERE call.call_set_name = 'SRS1098407' and reference_name = 'gi|1098495779|gb|MNPR01000669.1|'
        ORDER BY start"""
res = genomes.query_to_pandas_safe(query, max_gb_scanned=100)

res = res.values.tolist()
for r in res:
    print("\nreference_bases: ", r[1],
          "\nalternate_bases: ", r[2],
          "\nvariant_id: ", r[3],
          "\ntype: ",r[4],
          "\nstart-end: ",r[5],"-",r[6],"\n")
source.32084d3a:
query = """SELECT reference_name, reference_bases, alternate_bases, variant_id, TYPE, start, m.end
        FROM `bigquery-public-data.genomics_cannabis.MNPR01_201703` m, m.call
        WHERE reference_name = 'gi|1098495779|gb|MNPR01000669.1|' and m.end < 100
        ORDER BY start"""
res = genomes.query_to_pandas_safe(query, max_gb_scanned=100)

res = res.values.tolist()
   
positions = [0] * res[len(res)-1][6]
for r in res:
    for p in range(r[5],r[6]+1):
        positions[p-1] = positions[p-1]+1
print("      position | changes")
for p in range(len(positions)):
    print(f"{p+1:10}     |{positions[p]:5}")
source.84253bce:
Getting all the variations between samples from *SRS1098407 (blue dream)* and the reference sequence *gi|1098495779|gb|MNPR01000669.1|*.


I thought 1000 genomes meant 1000 whole genome sequences, I was wrong. What we have here are variants. Just variants.

Reference bases and alternate bases are the bases that were changed at position "start - end" of the reference genome.

The variant id identifies the variant. A "T" becoming a "G" at position 190-191, for example. This is not an ID for the row. The same variant happening on a different sample will have the same variant id.

The type is the type of variant. SNP is where a letter changes. I think you can guess what the other types mean.

source.0720fc15:
We can show how many changes there are at each position between the reference and all samples up to position 100.

Cannabis genomes (genomes in general, really) are, like, super long. If I tried to go through all the variants, it would take forever-de-ever to finish.
